reviewText: In Power Beauty Sweat, instructor Sara Ivanhoe does not rely on a traditional series of sun salutations to build heat in the body; rather, she adds movement to standing postures to intensify.  She begins in a seated position with a simple side stretch and twist, then moves to kneeling for a kneeling side stretch (gate pose) and side plank.  From here, the practice evolves to standing postures, including fan pose, a standing twist, and chair--each pose is repeated with movement and then a twist to both sides.  Balance work comes in the form of eagle pose, and then there is a series consisting of dog pose, lunge, runner's stretch, and cow (or bull) performed to both sides.  Dolphin pose further strengthens the arm muscles, and finally, there is a lying hamstring stretch.  As with all the practices in this series, Ivanhoe ends with a mudra--or yogic hand gesture--using a detoxification mudra here.Despite the title, I felt only minimal sweat as a result of this practice; it definitely did not build as much heat as a power yoga routine.  However, the large number of included twists felt wonderful for my spine, and the excellent hip openers felt great as well.  Instructor Sara Ivanhoe's personality in this practice is similar to her prior Crunch and Dummies videos: she is very down-to-earth, although some may find her language a bit patronizing at times.  Overall, this is a nice, short yoga routine for focusing on standing postures and streching the spine and hips.
summary: Nice routine with a standing posture and twist focus
Title: N/A

reviewText: For a while I've been on the lookout for shorter practices for busy days, but I held off on buying this one because I thought the title implied an over-emphasis on physical toning, etc., to the detriment of the `yogic' element. However, re-reading previous positive reviews here persuaded me to buy, and I must say I'm very pleased with my purchase. The 20 minutes are packed with interesting poses, nicely sequenced. I haven't come across Gate pose (which can be stepped up to Side Plank if you're more advanced) on a DVD before, and the twist added to Chair pose rings a pleasant change. Eagle doesn't feature all that often in other workouts either, and here it leaves me feeling amazingly grounded. The routine finishes off with Dolphin, another rare one. Sara Ivanhoe's instruction style is gentle but precise. It's nice to be able to feel stretched, strengthened and refreshed after only 20 minutes. A very useful DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: No, I don't sweat doing this workout, but I sure do feel great. Doing all those twisting poses makes me think that there is something to this "twisting poses are great for your digestion" claim.
summary: twist your way to feeling good
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm a busy person, so I'm always looking for short, to the point yoga practices.  I've been curious about this series for a while, so I gave it a shot.The primary emphasis of this practice is to detoxify through twists and some balance work.  Through the back cover, we're lead to believe that this will help burn calories and aid digestion; maybe it will help digestion, but the sweat just isn't there.  Though Ivanhoe offers some challenges with side plank (which can be modified) and Eagle (which, by the way, she sets up very well), you're not there long enough to build or hold heat.  She does have a very nice chair/twisting chair sequence (one of my pet postures), but again, we're not there long enough to get into calorie burning.However, this is a compact, soothing practice, and I enjoy the twists interspersed throughout the practice.  She also has some nice stretches for the legs and hips, so if you're feeling like you want a stretchy (but not acrobatic) practice, this could be for you.  I would also recommend it for people who have been consistently at the beginner level for the last few months but want to start pushing their boundaries a little bit.  Ivanhoe provides solid instruction and encouragement, so beginners should feel safe trying something new.
summary: A little bit of power, not too much sweat
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had mediocre expectations for this DVD given the reviews. But I like Sara's style and have 2 others in this series - sculpted buns & weight loss. So I tried it. I was surprised that I *really* like this workout. Of all in this series it has the most demanding poses for toning and strengthening - incl. dolphin and side plank. There is also a nice dose of detoxifying twists. My body feels like it does after a weight-lifting session at the gym.This workout really meets my abilities correctly. A yoga devotee for 3 yrs I consider myself an adv. beginner. There are some welcomed challenges here - but not so intense I am exceeding yogic values to avoid violent pushing of my body in my practice. This will take me to the next level and tone me up for my summer wardrobe.Don't get hung up on the title which says 'sweat.' If you sweat while lifting weights...then maybe you'll sweat here. If you don't...well, this is how you'll feel.
summary: The title should simply be 'Power Beauty.' Great workout!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was sorely disappointed with this DVD.  The poses are more like a warm-up for a more challenging routine that never comes.  When I finished with this DVD, I had to do another one just to feel like I had done something.  Not good at all.  I normally really love Sara and still like her approach, tone, voice, kind attitude, etc. but the workout was not a workout at all.  I will be selling my copy.  It isn't worth what I paid for it AT ALL!
summary: Normally love Sara... not this time... BAD WORKOUT!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I chose this separate DVD because of price, the instructor and the 20 minute factor. I have been doing Yoga on and off for the last couple of years but have recently been doing it twice a week. I liked this DVD because the moves were not the typical sun salutations taking up the beginning and the positions were challenging. As an intermediate on the lower end of the spectrum the 20 minutes worked. I did not sweat but I felt it in my legs the next day. The short session can almost guarantee that I will do this frequently by itself or along with a 30 minute cardio. I will probably look for the set to see what the others are like.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sara Ivanhoe brings a fresh approach to Yoga in her 20-minute routines where she presents modern adaptations to classic postures. The gentle flowing motions at the start almost seem to resemble a palm tree being slowly blown side to side in the breeze. You can imagine you are outside with rippling sapphire waves kissing the shoreline.Sara exercises on a beautiful lavender yoga mat set on a large wove mat set on the grass right next to the shoreline. She is out in the sun enjoying life and her exercises are inspiring. Instantly you feel yourself relaxing as your shoulders loosen and you move your arms above your head.Challenging sequences follow later with lovely moves such as twisty chair that allows you to monitor your "maintaining balance" progress. I had the thought that Yoga encourages peaceful contemplations, but if very challenging, no contemplations at all. This standing on one leg with one leg wrapped around the other is perhaps the ultimate balance challenge especially since you also have your arms wrapped around each other at the same time. The session ends with a mudra that seems to seal in the positive energy.I have come to the conclusion that the real reason I love Yoga is because you get to fall asleep at the end. A new way to use the workout to music without narration may be to just remain in final relaxation pose and dream you are at the beach.~The Rebecca Review
Title: N/A

reviewText: Power Beauty Sweat is another video in Sara's 20 Minute Yoga Makeover series and it's my favorite of the ones that I have tried.  I wouldn't necessarily agree with the title as other reviewers but I still enjoyed this practice quite a bit.  I really enjoyed the scenery which is a backdrop of the mountains and ocean in Hawaii, very colorful.You start by sitting on the floor in a cross legged position, you will first do a side lean to each side then a spinal twist.  Then you will come onto your knees for gate pose, where one leg is extended out and you lean over it.  You have the option of moving into stage 2 which is putting your arm behind you, I personally skip this.  Then you move into a side plank pose with a straight arm, this was tough for me, I may do this one on my elbow next time.  The option of moving into stage 2 by putting your arm behind you is given again here.  Gate and plank are then repeated on the other side.Then you will stand for fan pose, adding twists to each side before moving into a standing twist.  This is followed by chair pose twist, and eagle pose with a shoulder stretch.  You finish out with a nice series of poses such as downward facing dog, lunge stretch, hamstring stretch, cow pose, dolphin pose and a quadricep stretch while lying on your front.  Then you will end up in a cross legged position with a Mudra hand gesture.I would consider myself intermediate at best in yoga, I expected this practice to be harder than it was, though some poses were tougher for me than others.  But overall a very nice practice, I like doing this one in the mornings especially.  I like Sara Ivanhoe as an instructor and seem to click with her style of yoga.  Overall I give this one 4 and a half stars.
Title: N/A
